header.title: Our banknotes must feature ethnic minorities if we are to reflect modern Britain
header.postText: I am the co-creator of a campaign, alongside Patrick Vernon OBE, to secure the first ever ethnic minority person on a British banknote – something I believe to be truly important.', 'The face on a banknote is more than symbolic, it represents how a country sees itself.', 'The impressive figures of Winston Churchill, Jane Austen and Adam Smith currently grace our banknotes, but we need to see an equally influential ethnic minority figure taking a well-deserved place on the next re-issue of any of the polymer notes.', 'The people stamped upon our notes serve as ambassadors of a country, its identity and culture.', 'And as ethnic minority communities represent 14 per cent of the British population – a figure that could potentially double by 2050 – it’s high time our public institutions reflected modern Britain.', 'Our campaign and joint petition is the result of two separate petitions for banknote diversity, and we came together because the issue of representation is too important.', 'Patrick’s original petition focused on Mary Seacole, the Jamaican British nurse who supported British troops during the Crimean war. She has been recognised by the Royal College of Nursing as contributing as much as Florence Nightingale to British nursing.', 'My original petition focused on three heroines from the Second World War: Noor Inayat Khan, Violette Szabo and Odette Hallowes, all of whom were awarded the George Cross. To me, these brave women reflect the full diversity of British society.', 'Noor Inayat Khan is a personal heroine: a Muslim of Indian origin who was the first female radio operator to infiltrate enemy occupied France. Both my grandparents served in the British Indian Army, and she was someone that looked like me, who did extraordinary things in the service of the country – yet someone who I did not hear about at school.', 'The current lack of representation sends out a damaging message that no ethnic minority person has done anything of significance to appear. This is far from the case, and if we care about inclusion, we must tell these stories.', 'When will good, well-meaning policies on diversity and inclusion translate into the most visible form of representation?', 'Many know of William Wilberforce, who did so much to abolish slavery, but do people know the stories of black campaigners who risked so much, like Olaudah Equiano, who aided passage of the British Slave Trade Act of 1807?', 'I could give the example of Asian suffragettes like Sophie Duleep Singh, or we could go further back into history and speak of the first black Roman emperor, Septimius Severus.', 'Moreover, those ethnic minorities that were leading figures in their fields succeeded in spite of barriers to entry and progression.', 'The issue of being a ‘native’ subject at a time of empire meant limited rights, the legacy of slavery and living in a time that pre-dated equality legislation.', 'The former president of the Royal Society has also highlighted how scientists of colour in particular were often in the background and did not get recognition. This makes the Bank of England’s choice of scientist to feature on the new £50 particularly difficult one from the perspective of ethnic minority inclusion.', 'They did exist – take John Edmonstone, for example. He was a freed black slave from Guyana, South America who lived in Edinburgh and taught university students taxidermy. For one year he gave Charles Darwin lessons outside of the curriculum in taxidermy, natural studies and the flora and fauna of the South American continent.', 'The problems come when names like Edmonstone’s are put on shortlists with the likes of Alan Turing and Stephen Hawking. People from ethnic minorities may be put forward but historical bias means they simply cannot compete.', 'And that is why we would like to see one of the polymer notes (£5, £10, £20 or £50) re-issued to include the first ethnic minority.', 'The Bank of England made diversity a central pillar of its first strategic plan five years ago.', 'One year ago, the Governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney, noted that policies had to go beyond diversity alone and be truly inclusive. Today, across Whitehall, The Race Disparity Audit is one of the Government’s flagship policies.', 'When will good, well-meaning policies on diversity and inclusion translate into the most visible form of representation that the Bank of England could offer?', 'Yesterday, The Sunday Times published a letter supported by 220 signatories asking for ethnic minority representation on a banknote.', 'We were supported by cross-party politicians, grassroots campaigners, charity leaders from Joseph Rowntree Foundation, Barnardos, The Jo Cox Foundation and many more.', 'We also got the endorsement of actors, filmmakers, poets and writers, with supporters including, David Oyelowo OBE, Gemma Chan and Benjamin Zephaniah.', 'We believe inclusivity aids in helping to build more cohesive societies.', 'We can show the positive contribution that different groups make to this country and our shared history, and we can challenge stereotypes and build a narrative that inspires and motivates.', 'We do not want special treatment; we just want inclusion in shortlists based on talent and the make-up of modern Britain.', 'The faces on our banknotes can act as positive role models and get young people to think about those who contributed to our country.', 'Having the first ethnic minority on a banknote would send a message that the contribution of ethnic minority communities to Britain’s history, culture and economy matters.', 'The time has surely come.

commentThread.commentText: While I don’t disagree with your idea, Your claim of racial bias in reference to shortlisting John Edmonstone alongside the likes of Alan Turing and Stephen hawking is a bit skewed. You’re comparing a lecturer who tutored Charles Darwin for a year to people who, themselves DIRECTLY made discoveries or breakthroughs that heavily impacted the county/world.All scientists, Artists etc can be influenced by their peers during their education and development. But unless those peers have themselves done something of major significance you can’t demand for them to be put on bank notes and claim racial bias when they’re beat by people who have directly accomplished something significant on a national or global scale. Choices should be based on merit. There are commonwealth soldiers who were awarded Victoria crosses for outstanding feats of bravery that I would argue were more appropriate choices than your college lecturer.
